content.webTitle: Twisties and TV Hits: artist pays homage to the Australian milk bar in painstaking recreation

fields.headline: Twisties and TV Hits: artist pays homage to the Australian milk bar in painstaking recreation
fields.bodyText: Once a week, when Callum Preston was 13, he would put on an extra-large snow jacket and stand in a walk-in fridge. The fridge belonged to a milk bar in the Melbourne suburb of Westmeadows, and for a flat fee of $5 – and a promise that he could eat anything he wanted – Preston got to rotate its contents after school. It made him feel like a local legend: the kid who visited the milk bar so often, he got a job there. “Everyone I knew growing up went into that milk bar,” he says. “I got to see the behind the scenes ... it was a cool little status thing.” On Friday, the Melbourne-based artist launched his own tribute to the Australian suburban milk bar experience: a room-size replica full of faded, long-gone snacks, each handmade from plywood. “I went the extra mile and built the whole shop. You’re standing inside the artwork rather than standing looking at it on a wall.” Preston has created more than 500 handmade items, from magazines and chip packets, to wooden Panadol containers and dish soap. Most are 2D, painted on, and mounted upright like small trophies. “A bag of Twisties has a natural bulge to it that doesn’t work in a rectangle,” he says. It’s an artwork primarily concerned with nostalgia and aesthetics, but Preston says the experience of remaking hundreds of retro items also revealed a lot about how consumer goods, multinational companies and food had changed. “It’s been a good exercise in reminding myself,” he says. “These products change over time and we don’t really notice it. Big companies change the branding, chip away at it. A can of Fanta from 1996 is very different to one now – most things you buy these days have extra things attached to the design– the ‘limited release chocolate caramel’ version of the Mars bar or whatever. “A dozen flavours of soft drink now seem silly when there’s basically a dozen flavours of Red Bull you can get. The beauty I’ve seen, in making them all, is there was a very level playing field [back then]. Things weren’t designed to trick you into thinking they were something else.” Callum Preston’s Milk Bar, which will live in Collingwood’s RVCA Corner Gallery, is also an attempt to recreate the sense of community he discovered as a child, “in the teenage gap where you’re old enough to have freedom, but too young to go to a pub or club”. “When I was a kid, the guy who ran the milk bar was kind of the neighbourhood directory. In those suburbs you’re a bit of a local gatekeeper I guess.” Callum used plywood (“The A4 of building materials”), and cut, glued and painted each piece by hand. He spent a lot of time researching, but ultimately every item was created mostly from his own memory, and they are not exact replicas. “There’s definitely liberties taken throughout the show,” he says. “I tried to work in a limited colour palette – not everything has to be the exact right shade. I also tried to not use the same paint twice. “What I love about milk bars is that they’re not intentionally set-dressed to look that way: it’s just dysfunction,” he says. “Whatever the chip companies send them, they put them on the wall. The ice-cream brands might want the fridge painted a certain way. “You get a real clash of colours and signs, it’s like a mini Las Vegas. As opposed to a modern cafe, where you would consult with people. It’s got an aesthetic that is unintentional.” But while a lot has changed, the milk bar where Preston first worked at remains. “I visited it recently,” he says. “The original owner is a few generations gone, it’s been sold on and sold on. But the store itself is still there. “I imagine there’s probably people who used to be kids in the neighbourhood who grew up going there, who still have a connection to it and shop there. There’s a supermarket now just down the road, but it seems to be standing up.” When asked to pick a favourite item from the time – the one that brings back the most nostalgia – he can’t. “Everyone has a product that they reminisce on ... but not for me,” he says. “I wanted the whole store, so I built the whole store.” Callum Preston’s Milk Bar is open 2, 3, 8, 9 and 10 December, from 11am – 4pm, at RVCA Corner Gallery, Collingwood, Melbourne.
